author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
title: A Record Virus Surge in the Philippines, but Doctors Are Hopeful
description: Health officials say recent infections have been milder than those seen in previous waves, though they are still urging caution.
content: The Philippines is grappling with a Covid-19 surge that has accelerated at a pace not seen since the start of the pandemic. But fewer people are severely ill than in previous waves, an encouraging sign for countries bracing for a similar rise in cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Persistent Gender Gap at the Supreme Court Lectern
description: More than 40 years after Ruth Bader Ginsburg last appeared as a lawyer at the Supreme Court, relatively few women argue cases there.
content: WASHINGTON — In her final appearance as a lawyer before the Supreme Court, in 1978, Ruth Bader Ginsburg argued in favor of the equal treatment of women in the justice system. She made her case to nine men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas McNamee
title: A Slaughter of Wolves Like This Hasn’t Been Seen in a Century
description: Wolves have thrived since returning to the Northern Rockies. Now they face relentless assault by hunters and trappers.
content: LIVINGSTON, Mont. — A slaughter of wolves is underway in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming that has no precedent in the past 100 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Launches 2 Short-Range Ballistic Missiles
description: The recent missile activity has raised tensions in the region at a sensitive time, and has prompted the United States to call for more sanctions on the North.
content: SEOUL — North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast on Monday, in its fourth weapons test in a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Democrats Press Ahead With Debate on Voting Rights Bill
description: The Senate on Tuesday will begin to debate new voting rights protections, even though the measure appears all but dead in the face of two key Democratic defections.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats plan to press ahead this week with an effort to push new voting rights protections through Congress, in an all but doomed attempt to enact a key piece of President Biden’s agenda that has been undercut by members of his own party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Dictator’s Son Can Stay in Philippine Presidential Race, Officials Say
description: With Ferdinand Marcos Jr. leading in the polls, victims of his father’s regime have not given up their fight to keep his name off the ballot.
content: MANILA — The Philippines Commission on Elections on Monday threw out a petition to disqualify Ferdinand Marcos Jr. from the May presidential election, one of several efforts to keep the son of the former dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos off the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Belgian farmhouse-style home in Beverly Hills, a Craftsman bungalow in Los Gatos and a cottage in Carmel-by-the-Sea.
content: This house is on Benedict Canyon Drive, a twisty road that leads from the heart of Beverly Hills to Mulholland Drive, considered by most to be the dividing line between Beverly Hills and the San Fernando Valley. Benedict Canyon and the streets just off it are popular with buyers looking for privacy and proximity to hiking spots like Franklin Canyon Park and Stone Canyon Reservoir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genna Martin
title: The Eerie, Lunar Nothingness of Namibia’s Skeleton Coast
description: The stretch of coastline in southwest Africa is a strange and beautiful reminder that, in the end, we are powerless against nature and time.
content: We had been driving for four hours and had yet to see another soul. No people. No cars. Just eerie, lunar nothingness stretching south to the horizon. To the left, desert; to the right, ocean. A packed salt road sewed a tight seam between the two. Under an overcast sky, the three surfaces faded into a single indistinguishable gray-brown smear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Economy Is Slowing, a Worrying Sign for the World
description: Economic output climbed 4 percent in the last quarter of 2021, slowing from the previous quarter. Growth has faltered as home buyers and consumers become cautious.
content: BEIJING — Construction and property sales have slumped. Small businesses have shut because of rising costs and weak sales. Debt-laden local governments are cutting the pay of civil servants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Aina J. Khan
title: A Tense Texas Standoff Leads to Emotional Phone Call Between Brothers
description: Gulbar Akram described his brother, Faisal, who was holding four hostages in a Texas synagogue on Saturday, as deeply troubled. He said he worked with the police to try to “talk him down.’’
content: BLACKBURN, England — The conversation was urgent and emotional as Gulbar Akram huddled with the police in Manchester, England, on Saturday and spoke with his brother, who was holding four people hostage at a synagogue almost 5,000 miles away in Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: A Love of Trees or a Display of Power? The Odd Park of an Oligarch.
description: A billionaire former prime minister says he has retired from Georgia’s fraught politics. His critics say he still wields considerable power. What’s beyond dispute: his obsession with trees.
content: SHEKVETILI, Georgia — Over the past five years, people in Georgia witnessed a surreal spectacle: giant, even centuries-old trees floating upright on the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Kim
title: The Too-Short Evolution of Mac Miller
description: “Most Dope,” a biography by Paul Cantor, offers a tender remembrance of a precocious talent.
content: MOST DOPEThe Extraordinary Life of Mac MillerBy Paul Cantor
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Two members of the Joint Chiefs test positive for the coronavirus.
description: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman, and Gen. David H. Berger, the commandant of the Marine Corps, were both vaccinated.
content: Two members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, including the chairman, have tested positive for the coronavirus, Pentagon officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaevon Williams
title: What’s on TV This Week: Michelle Obama and ‘Billions’
description: A conversation with Michelle Obama airs on BET. And Showtime’s “Billions” begins a new season.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 17-23. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below, along with some solving tips and tricks by Wordplay’s own Deb Amlen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Eastern Europe Tests New Forms of Media Censorship
description: With new, less repressive tactics, countries like Serbia, Poland and Hungary are deploying highly effective tools to skew public opinion.
content: BELGRADE, Serbia — When Covid-19 reached Eastern Europe in the spring of 2020, a Serbian journalist reported a severe shortage of masks and other protective equipment. She was swiftly arrested, thrown in a windowless cell and charged with inciting panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Witness,’ Seeking a Haven for Jewish Refugees
description: The experience of Jews who fled Germany in 1939 aboard the St. Louis luxury liner is the subject of a new production from the Arlekin Players Theater.
content: Aboard the luxury liner St. Louis, more than 900 passengers waited helplessly at sea. In May 1939, on the eve of World War II, they were Jewish refugees fleeing post-Kristallnacht Germany. Despite having papers meant to let them into Cuba, they were barred from disembarking once they got there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: BBC Funding Frozen for 2 Years as Cabinet Minister Attacks Public Fee
description: The license fee on TV owners makes up three-quarters of the British broadcaster’s income and is guaranteed until 2027.
content: Over the weekend, a British government minister tried to deal a death blow to the main source of funding for the BBC, a license fee charged each year to any household with a TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Poroshenko, Ex-President, Returns to Ukraine, Roiling Politics
description: Petro O. Poroshenko, a former president, returned to Kyiv on Monday facing possible arrest, adding internal political turmoil to a threat of Russian invasion.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s former president and a leading opposition figure, Petro O. Poroshenko, returned Monday to Kyiv, where he faced possible arrest on charges of treason, adding internal political turmoil to the mounting threat of a Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shuaib Almosawa, Vivian Yee and Isabella Kwai
title: Yemen’s Houthi Militia Claims Rare Military Strike on U.A.E.
description: Emirati officials said that several people had been killed in an explosion of fuel tankers in Abu Dhabi, apparently caused by a drone attack.
content: SANA, Yemen — The Iran-backed Houthi militia in Yemen attacked the United Arab Emirates on Monday in an apparent drone strike that blew up several fuel tankers and killed three people, according to state-run Emirati media and Houthi officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Catherine Porter
title: Winter Storm Drops Heavy Snow in the Northeast as the South Digs Out
description: The storm pummeled parts of the U.S. and Canada over the holiday weekend, leaving two dead and thousands without power in the Southeast. More than 1,700 flights were canceled.
content: A strong winter storm that slammed the South with snow showers and ice over the weekend moved north on Monday, dropping heavy snow over parts of the Northeast and Canada, where gusty winds made travel treacherous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward, Azi Paybarah and Eileen Sullivan
title: 11 Hours of Fear, Negotiation and Finally, Relief
description: The F.B.I. identified Malik Faisal Akram, a British national, as the man who took hostages in a Texas synagogue on Saturday. He was killed during the rescue operation.
content: Just before New Year’s, a 44-year-old man from an industrial city in the north of England landed at Kennedy International Airport. On his travel documents, he listed his destination as a hotel on Queens Boulevard. His arrival raised no red flags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Janis Ian Lets Her Music Speak Her Mind (One Last Time)
description: At 70, the singer-songwriter who has always been unafraid of difficult subjects is releasing a final album, “The Light at the End of the Line.”
content: On a recent morning, Janis Ian spoke expansively from her work space in Florida about a 50-year career marked by literary lyrics, social activism and major hits. Just one subject brought her up short. When pondering younger artists who’ve publicly cited her as an inspiration, she paused and threw up her arms. “I can’t think of one. So many people say, ‘Joni Mitchell is my big influence,’” she said. “And I thought, wait a minute. Didn’t I influence anybody?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: A North Sea Auction Produces Big Plans for Scottish Wind Farms
description: Oil giants like BP and Shell propose to spend billions on renewable energy, bolstering Scotland’s efforts to move away from an economy based on fossil fuel.
content: Oil giants like BP and Shell as well as Iberdrola, the Spanish utility, look like the big winners in Scotland’s first offshore wind auction, whose results were announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Covid, China, Trump: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Michael Levenson
title: Officials Investigating Synagogue Attacker’s Link to 2010 Terror Case
description: Aafia Siddiqui has spent almost 12 years in a U.S. federal prison after being convicted of trying to kill American soldiers and plotting to blow up the Statue of Liberty.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — The tabloids called her Lady Qaeda. A neuroscientist who was educated at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she was accused of trying to kill American soldiers and plotting to blow up the Statue of Liberty. Since then, Aafia Siddiqui has spent almost 12 years in a federal prison in Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A Strong New Lead in ‘The Betrayal of Anne Frank’
description: Rosemary Sullivan’s new book chronicles the emergence of a new suspect who might have informed the authorities of Frank’s whereabouts.
content: The title of Rosemary Sullivan’s important new book, “The Betrayal of Anne Frank,” resounds far beyond its primary meaning. Sullivan is chronicling the investigation of a cold case, the unsolved mystery of who alerted authorities in the summer of 1944 to the hiding place of Frank, her family and four other Jewish people, above a pectin and spice warehouse in Nazi-occupied Amsterdam, resulting in their arrest and deportation to concentration camps. Two official investigations, begun in 1947 and 1963, failed to reveal the identity of the informant; the matter has preoccupied multiple biographers since. Sullivan writes with absolute dedication and precision, bringing a previously obscure suspect to the fore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arnold Schwarzenegger
title: Schwarzenegger: We Put Solar Panels on 1 Million Roofs in California. That Win Is Now Under Threat.
description: Removing incentives to encourage homeowners to install solar panels is a bad idea.
content: California has more rooftops with solar panels than any other state and continues to be a leader in new installations. But a proposal from the state’s public utility commission threatens that progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Sales of Electric Vehicles Surpass Diesel in Europe, a First
description: The popularity of battery-powered cars is soaring while the overall auto market stagnates, a worldwide trend.
content: Europeans bought more electric cars than diesels in December, a stunning illustration of the growing popularity of battery power and the decline of diesel, which was once the most popular engine option in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: In a Double Bill, the Avant-Garde Meets a Very Good Girl
description: Excellent performances, including one by a well-behaved dog, warm up two experimental plays upstate.
content: CHATHAM, N.Y. — There is nothing less avant-garde than a dog. Put one onstage and the artiest notions immediately dissolve into Instagram moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Airlines Warn of Chaos if 5G Mobile Service Is Deployed This Week
description: Thousands of planes could be grounded because the new internet technology interferes with sensors, the industry reiterated in a letter to federal officials.
content: Two days before Verizon and AT&T plan to deploy more segments of their new 5G mobile internet technology, leaders of the nation’s largest air carriers warned again on Monday that thousands of flights could be grounded by interference from the technology and that “the nation’s commerce will grind to a halt.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: America’s Ugliest Confederate Statue Is Gone. Racism Isn’t.
description: The act of taking down a memorial — like the act of putting one up — is largely symbolic. But  symbols also tell us who we are.
content: NASHVILLE — God knows I didn’t visit the Tennessee State Museum last week to pay my respects to the bust of Nathan Bedford Forrest, but while I was there I figured I might as well take a look. It’s been quite a year for the Confederate general, slave trader and grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: After ‘Clyde’s,’ Lynn Nottage Just Has Two Shows Onstage. ‘Whew!’
description: With one play closed, Nottage can focus on “MJ” on Broadway and “Intimate Apparel” at Lincoln Center Theater. And maybe even catch her breath.
content: It was just a flute of champagne after Sunday’s final Broadway performance of her play “Clyde’s,” but Lynn Nottage was genuinely happy to have it — not only to toast the end of the limited run with the rest of the company, upstairs at the Hayes Theater, but also to sneak a brief, rare moment of indulgence in a schedule that’s lately been too crammed for a glass of wine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 17, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 17, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold, Ana Ley, James Thomas and Benjamin Norman
title: Here’s Where Subway Riders Have Returned. And Where They Haven’t.
description: We talked to New Yorkers at stations in Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan. Their experiences riding the subway hint at the barriers to drawing back those who are not.
content: The sun rises on a weekday in New York City, and at a Queens subway station the daily grind resembles its old self: Thousands of people pile onto an open-air platform above a bustling neighborhood, waiting in the cold to crowd onto rush-hour trains toward work, school and other essential appointments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Djokovic Returns to Warm Embrace in Home Country of Serbia
description: Novak Djokovic’s deportation from Australia over his vaccination status could signal future difficulties in his quest to win a record 21st tennis Grand Slam title.
content: BELGRADE, Serbia — Novak Djokovic, undone in his quest for a 10th Australian Open tennis championship by his decision to remain unvaccinated against Covid-19, returned on Monday to the warm embrace of his home nation of Serbia even as his future in the sport was shrouded in uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China decides not to sell Olympics tickets to the Chinese public.
description: China had already barred foreign spectators from attending the Winter Games that begin in Beijing in less than a month. On Monday, it announced that most Chinese people won’t be able to attend either.
content: China had already barred foreign spectators from attending the Winter Games that begin in Beijing in less than a month. On Monday, it announced that most Chinese people won’t be able to attend either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Try Intuitive Eating to Break the Diet Cycle
description: Today’s Eat Well Challenge will help you avoid the “what-the-hell” effect and tune into your body instead.
content: Diet. Cheat. Give Up. Repeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: French Far-Right Candidate Convicted for Inciting Racial Hatred
description: Éric Zemmour, a pundit whose presidential run has upended French politics, had called unaccompanied migrant children “murderers” and “rapists” on television.
content: PARIS — Éric Zemmour, the anti-immigrant far-right pundit who is running in France’s presidential elections, was convicted on Monday on charges of inciting racial hatred and making racially insulting comments after saying on television in 2020 that unaccompanied child migrants were “thieves,” “rapists,” and “murderers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Alexandra Stevenson
title: China’s Births Hit Historic Low, a Political Problem for Beijing
description: The demographic crisis, a challenge to the economy, also signals a limit to the reach of the government, which has struggled recently to grow the population.
content: China announced on Monday that its birthrate plummeted for a fifth straight year in 2021, moving the world’s most populous country closer to the potentially seismic moment when its population will begin to shrink, and hastening a demographic crisis that could undermine its economy and even its political stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Welcome to the ‘Well, Now What?’ Stage of the Story
description: It’s been a very long year for Joe Biden.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I suspect that even some diligent readers roll their eyes and turn the proverbial page when the subject of the filibuster comes up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: After Quarantine, Keeping Up the Korda Family Tradition
description: Sebastian Korda’s father and sisters have won in Australia. Now, Korda has recorded his first Australian Open win.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Sebastian Korda spent his first week of a long-awaited trip to Australia far from the summer sunshine he imagined: After testing positive for the coronavirus upon landing in the country, Korda was quarantined in a hotel room in Adelaide, hitting a ball against the headboard of his bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: In London Shops, Greek Cheese, Sicilian Citrus and British Headaches
description: For companies depending on fast, small deliveries, the costs of new Brexit trade rules are mounting.
content: LONDON — In a warehouse tucked under two railway arches in southeast London is a treasure trove of Greek delicacies, including barrel-aged feta, fresh oregano, Cretan olive oil and cases of nearly a hundred different wines destined for the city’s top restaurants and discerning home cooks. But as Britain phases in Brexit-required customs rules with the European Union, the tempting variety at Maltby & Greek is under threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: The Real Roots of the Debate Over Schools During Covid
description: How “taxpayer” became just another kind of consumer.
content: Last week’s newsletter generated a lot of feedback via email and social media. I will respond to some of the interesting bits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: When Dementia Strikes at an Early Age
description: Dementia in a person in their 30s, 40s or 50s poses special challenges, starting with getting a diagnosis.
content: Many people aren’t overly concerned when an octogenarian occasionally forgets the best route to a favorite store, can’t remember a friend’s name or dents the car while trying to parallel park on a crowded city street. Even healthy brains work less efficiently with age, and memory, sensory perceptions and physical abilities become less reliable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
title: Philippines grapples with a record surge after the holidays.
description: The Philippines is grappling with a Covid-19 surge that has accelerated at a pace not seen since the start of the pandemic. But fewer people are severely ill than in previous waves, an encouraging sign for countries bracing for a similar rise in cases.
content: The Philippines is grappling with a Covid-19 surge that has accelerated at a pace not seen since the start of the pandemic. But fewer people are severely ill than in previous waves, an encouraging sign for countries bracing for a similar rise in cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: News analysis: Variants force the C.D.C. to make decisions with scant data.
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was long revered for its methodical and meticulous scientific approach. Agencies in other nations modeled themselves after the world’s most highly regarded public health authority, even adopting the name.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was long revered for its methodical and meticulous scientific approach. Agencies in other nations modeled themselves after the world’s most highly regarded public health authority, even adopting the name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Pelicans Choose to Remain Upbeat, Not Beaten Down
description: New Orleans guard Josh Hart is assembling his most complete pro season under a new coach who is relentlessly positive, and for a team that is still missing Zion Williamson.
content: BOSTON — Josh Hart has experienced quite a bit. He won a national championship at Villanova. He played alongside LeBron James with the Los Angeles Lakers. He reached great heights and scrambled for minutes. But Hart got a dose of something new at the start of this N.B.A. season with the New Orleans Pelicans: relentless positivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: Custom 1951 Mercury Sells at Auction for $1.95 Million
description: The Hirohata Merc, a prime example of the custom car scene that blossomed in midcentury Southern California, notched two records in its sale.
content: A customized 1951 Mercury coupe astonished aficionados over the weekend, selling for $1.95 million at the Mecum collector car auction in Kissimmee, Fla., outpacing the vehicle’s presale estimate of up to $1.25 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Limits Olympic Spectators
description: Tickets for the Winter Olympics will not be sold to the public.
content: China had already barred foreign spectators from attending the Winter Games that begin in Beijing on Feb. 4. On Monday, it announced that most Chinese people won’t be able to attend either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Keith, Desiree Rios, Ahmed Gaber, David Dee Delgado and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Scenes From a Weekend of Mourning in the Bronx
description: Prayer services were held for 15 of the 17 victims of the fire that broke out last week at the Twin Parks North West building.
content: Funeral services were held on Sunday to commemorate 17 lives lost a week ago when New York City’s deadliest fire in decades tore through an apartment building in the Bronx. All the victims were of West African origin, from Gambia, Mali and Guinea. Half of them were children; the youngest was 2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Cowboys Come Up Short Against 49ers Long Before Clunky Finish
description: The No. 6-seeded 49ers upset the No. 3-seeded Cowboys after a chaotic final drive that will prolong Dallas’s disappointment.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — There are certain expectations, vast as the horizon, for the local professional football team, and when those expectations go unmet and unfulfilled — as they have for almost three decades and counting — another disappointing Dallas Cowboys season begets an eventful Dallas Cowboys off-season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: For Two Roommates, the Fine Print Held a Big Surprise
description: The two young women had a lot to learn, but they came out on top in Brooklyn with a self-guided crash course on the New York City real estate market.
content: “One of the hardest parts about moving to New York,” Ruthie Landry said, “is finding out about renters’ rights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The C.D.C.’s New Challenge? Grappling With Imperfect Science
description: The Omicron coronavirus variant is moving much faster than researchers can, worsening a longstanding problem: The agency must make tough decisions with scant data.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was long revered for its methodical and meticulous scientific approach. Agencies in other nations modeled themselves after the world’s most highly regarded public health authority, even adopting the name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Just when Broadway figures out how to keep shows running, the audiences vanish.
description: The reopening of Broadway last summer, after its longest shutdown in history, provided a jolt of energy to a city ready for a rebound: Bruce Springsteen and block parties, eager audiences and enthusiastic actors.
content: The reopening of Broadway last summer, after its longest shutdown in history, provided a jolt of energy to a city ready for a rebound: Bruce Springsteen and block parties, eager audiences and enthusiastic actors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Melanie Lynskey on That Chilling ‘Yellowjackets’ Finale
description: The actress discussed her character’s cool under pressure, her favorite fan theories and one thing she insisted to writers that Shauna would never do.
content: This interview contains major spoilers from the season finale of “Yellowjackets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: The chairman of Credit Suisse resigns after an inquiry into his pandemic conduct.
description: António Horta-Osório is out, less than a year after he stepped into the role.
content: The chairman of the Credit Suisse Group, António Horta-Osório, is stepping down immediately after an investigation involving breaches of Covid protocol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Ralph Emery, the Dick Clark of Country Music, Dies at 88
description: For six decades he promoted country performers on radio and television, earning a place in the Country Music Hall of Fame.
content: NASHVILLE — Ralph Emery, the M.C. widely regarded as the most popular radio and television broadcast personality in the history of country music, died on Saturday at a hospital here. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham, Jacey Fortin and Troy Closson
title: The Hostages Escaped. But Synagogues Ask, How Can They Be More Secure?
description: The hostages whispered instructions and edged closer to the door — part of invaluable training that anxious congregations are using.
content: DALLAS — For 11 hours, the hostages talked to the ranting gunman, hoping that he would see them as human. They whispered about strategies. And they surreptitiously edged toward the nearest exit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: A Grand Miami Beach Hotel, and Its History, Might Be Torn Down
description: The Deauville Beach Resort played host to The Beatles, Frank Sinatra and John F. Kennedy. But it has been deemed unsafe after years of neglect.
content: MIAMI BEACH — The baby-faced Beatles spent nine sun-kissed days in Miami Beach in 1964, basking in the warm winter as thousands of young fans thronged to catch a glimpse of the four Liverpool lads enjoying a bit of freedom on the ocean shore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: Alone With a Basketball, a Hoop, and Covid
description: Separated from his family, he launched jump shots in the driveway and wondered: Will we ever properly mourn the ones we’ve lost? Will we ever smile again? The answers were hit or miss.
content: This is about basketball, not about Covid. Or maybe it’s about basketball in the time of Covid. Or maybe I’m just not thinking clearly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Nailah Avery
title: Behind the Movement to Create More Black Video Game Characters
description: The lack of Black representation in games stems from a failure to understand the Black gaming audience, creators say.
content: Thirteen-year-old Edward Leonard of Bloomfield, Conn., has a message for the video game industry: “I would like to see more Black leads.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Threats from Russia.
content: Extensive negotiations last week did not defuse the security crisis that Moscow has ignited in Eastern Europe. Ukraine remains surrounded on three sides by 100,000 Russian troops, and Russia has issued subtle but wide-ranging threats, including hinting that it could place nuclear missiles close to the U.S. if the West did not meet its security demands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Omicron and the Need for Speed
description: The variant is forcing the C.D.C. to make decisions at a breakneck pace
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was long revered for its methodical and meticulous scientific approach. But the Omicron variant is forcing the C.D.C. to make some decisions at a breakneck pace, my colleague Apoorva Mandavilli reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: A Fighter for Press Freedom Is Expanding Her Battle
description: Jodie Ginsberg, a veteran British journalist and advocate, will become the president of the Committee to Protect Journalists at a time when attacks on the press are at an all-time high.
content: Jodie Ginsberg was leading a small, scrappy freedom of expression organization in London in 2014 when the Bahraini human rights activist Nabeel Rajab came into her office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick, Anne Barnard and Lola Fadulu
title: The Bronx Fire Victims: Passionate Students and Hardworking Parents
description: The victims, eight children and nine adults, came from a tight-knit community of West African immigrants.
content: The smoky blaze that took 17 lives in the Bronx a week ago Sunday tore at the heart of a tiny, tight-knit community of Gambian immigrants in New York City. The toll stood at nine adults and eight children, the city’s largest loss of life in a single fire in decades. Nearly all the victims were Gambian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: What the Supreme Court’s Vaccine Case Was Really About
description: The justices are turning around long-established law giving government agencies running room to do their jobs.
content: Halfway through their pained dissent from the Supreme Court’s decision blocking the Biden administration’s workplace Covid vaccine rule, the court’s three liberal justices made a glancing reference to a now-obscure case from 1981, American Textile Manufacturers Institute v. Donovan. It was one of the court’s first efforts to interpret the 1970 law that created the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Unilever Pursues Glaxo and Pfizer Consumer Health Venture
description: Rejected three times, Unilever suggests it will keep fighting to acquire a giant in the world of pain relievers, toothpastes and cold treatments.
content: LONDON — The company behind Advil, ChapStick and Tums is the target of the first big multibillion-dollar takeover fight of 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: In Volcano’s Aftermath, an Agonizing Wait for Tonga News
description: Overseas Tongans were desperately seeking word from their loved ones after a huge undersea eruption severed communications lines two days ago.
content: Two days after a colossal volcanic eruption spawned a tsunami that struck the island nation of Tonga, severed communication lines left Tongans around the world waiting anxiously for news of their loved ones, while aid agencies and the country’s Pacific neighbors struggled to assess the scale of the damage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Renegade Pop Music Genre Challenges the Old Guard
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 17, 2022.
content: “Mahraganat taught us that you can do something new and it will be heard.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
description: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
content: The downtown of Sunnyvale, Calif., has been bustling since the coronavirus pandemic started. More than a thousand visitors have enjoyed a night on the town practically every evening for almost two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
title: Who Is King of Florida? Tensions Rise Between Trump and a Former Acolyte.
description: A spat over Covid has exposed friction between the former president and a rising G.O.P. governor unwilling to curb his ambitions.
content: For months, former President Donald J. Trump has been grumbling quietly to friends and visitors to his Palm Beach mansion about a rival Republican power center in another Florida mansion, some 400 miles to the north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Ashley Southall
title: Woman Pushed Onto Subway Tracks ‘Never Saw’ Her Attacker
description: “She was just the person who did everything right,” a neighbor said of Michelle Go, who died on Saturday when a homeless man pushed her in front of an R train.
content: Michelle Alyssa Go loved New York City, and traveling. She had celebrated her 40th birthday in December with a vacation in the Maldives, a neighbor said, and looked forward to work-related business trips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert C. Yeager
title: Boom Times for Classic Car Auctions Conducted Online
description: Bring a Trailer had a huge year, but rivals big and small are planning to grab a piece of this market, which the pandemic has accelerated at a breakneck pace.
content: Joe Sackey figures that over the past three decades he has privately sold cars worth $200 million. But last year, as Bring a Trailer, the fast-growing auction site for collectible cars was booming, Mr. Sackey and his son Sterling sensed opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: On the Scene: Trump's Latest Rally
description: At the first Trump rally since President Biden accused his predecessor of holding “a dagger at the throat of America,” the conservative outrage at the current president was palpable.
content: At the first Trump rally since President Biden accused his predecessor of holding “a dagger at the throat of America,” the conservative outrage at the current president was palpable.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3.2 Million in California
description: A Belgian farmhouse-style home in Beverly Hills, a 1910 Craftsman in Los Gatos and a cottage in Carmel-by-the-Sea.
content: A Belgian farmhouse-style home in Beverly Hills, a 1910 Craftsman in Los Gatos and a cottage in Carmel-by-the-Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful, Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Northern States See a Wintry Mix of Snow, Ice and Rain
description: A strong winter storm spread into the Northeast after slamming parts of the South, bringing heavy snow and causing hundreds of flight cancellations.
content: A strong winter storm spread into the Northeast after slamming parts of the South, bringing heavy snow and causing hundreds of flight cancellations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Network Pool and Reuters
title: Martin Luther King Jr.’s Family Tells Senate to Legislate, ‘Not Celebrate’
description: Relatives of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. marched on Washington and urged the Senate to pass voting rights legislation.
content: Relatives of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. marched on Washington and urged the Senate to pass voting rights legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mothers, Absent and Present
description: Not all mothers have the luxury of being “absent,” a reader writes. Also: A lawsuit against 16 elite schools; the heart of Christianity; jobs in manufacturing.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Chicken meatball soup, potato and cheese pierogi, and more recipes.
content: Good morning. It’s Martin Luther King Jr. Day, a day of service for many, and of reflection. You may wish to get to recipes right away, but I’ll put this out there for those who would like to take a moment before we light the stoves: King’s sermon on loving your enemies, delivered in the late 1950s at Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala.
source.name: The New York Times
